chapter.title: WidgetProcessors
chapter.para: This chapter covers each WidgetProcessor in detail. For an explanation of how WidgetProcessors fit into the overall architecture of Metawidget, see .

section.title: Desktop WidgetProcessors
section.para: Metawidget supports multiple WidgetProcessors for each desktop framework, targeting specific features within each environment.

section.title: Property Binding
section.para: Swing does not include an automatic JComponent to Object binding mechanism, but Metawidget supports third-party alternatives via addWidgetProcessor.

section.title: BeansBindingProcessor
section.para: BeansBindingProcessor binds properties using Beans Binding (JSR-295). It supports the various Beans Binding update strategies:

If set to READ or READ_WRITE (the default is READ_ONCE), the object being inspected must provide PropertyChangeSupport. If set to READ_WRITE, updates to the UI are automatically sync'ed back to the setToInspect, otherwise the client must manually call save:
After JComponents have been generated for the initial setToInspect, clients can load values for a new Object into the same UI without a full re-inspection by using rebind:
For more details, see .
section.important: Make sure you use the correct version of BeansBinding There are unfortunately two versions of BeansBinding 1.2.1 available. The version at http://repo2.maven.org/maven2/net/java/dev/beansbinding/beansbinding/1.2.1 has serious bugs related to PropertyChangeListeners. The version at http://download.java.net/maven/2/org/jdesktop/beansbinding/1.2.1 is the correct one. This issue has been reported here.
section.tip: Consider BetterBeansBinding BeansBinding 1.2.1 has known performance issues when working with large numbers of widgets. Consider a more recent JSR-295 implementation such as BetterBeansBinding.

section.title: Action Binding
section.para: Swing supplies javax.swing.Action for binding JButtons to backing objects, and this is typically combined with Java-based reflection to support runtime binding. This is exactly what the default action binding, ReflectionBinding, does.

section.title: Web WidgetProcessors
section.para: Metawidget supports multiple WidgetProcessors for each Web framework, targeting specific features within each environment.

section.title: Property Binding
section.para: Like most other Metawidgets, GwtMetawidget supports property binding. Property binding generally requires reflection, and GWT recommends using Generators to achieve this. As of the time of writing, however, much of the burden of implementation rests on the developer.

section.title: StyleNameProcessor
section.para: StyleNameProcessor sets styleName on all generated widgets, based on the styleName of the parent Metawidget. It does not 'drill into' Stubs.

section.title: AngularWidgetProcessor
section.para: WidgetProcessor to add Angular JS bindings and validation, and compile the widget.

section.title: BootstrapWidgetProcessor
section.para: WidgetProcessor to add CSS styles for Bootstrap. For example, adds:

section.title: IdProcessor
section.para: WidgetProcessor that sets the 'id' attribute.

section.title: RequiredAttributeProcessor
section.para: WidgetProcessor that sets the 'required' attribute.

section.title: SimpleBindingProcessor
section.para: Simple data/action binding implementation. Frameworks that supply their own data-binding mechanisms should override this with their own WidgetProcessor.
SimpleBindingProcessor binds properties using widget.value. To save values back into the business object, clients must call save:

SimpleBindingProcessor can also reload the values in the widgets. This is independent of toInspect, and it doesn't save any values back from the widgets. But it can be useful in Node.js environments for re-populating the widgets based on an HTTP request POST-back:

section.title: AjaxProcessor
section.para: AjaxProcessor adds a JSF 2.0 AjaxBehavior to any widgets with a faces-ajax-action attribute.

section.title: CssStyleProcessor
section.para: CssStyleProcessor sets style and styleClass properties on all generated widgets, based on the style and styleClass of the parent Metawidget. It does not 'drill into' UIStubs.

section.title: HiddenFieldProcessor
section.para: Many Web applications store their data at the HttpServletRequest level, not at the HttpSession level. Using session-level state (or, ideally, a UI framework that supports some kind of 'conversation'-level state) is safer than passing variables to and from the client in hidden HTML fields. However, for those that need this approach HiddenFieldProcessor wraps a Stub containing an HtmlInputHidden around read-only values, so that they POST back.

section.title: ImmediateAttributeProcessor
section.para: ImmediateAttributeProcessor sets UIInput.setImmediate for any widgets with a faces-immediate attribute.

section.title: LabelProcessor
section.para: LabelProcessor sets JSF 1.2's setLabel for those UIComponents that support it. This label is used during validation errors and conversion errors (even if the UIComponent does not explicitly have a converter).

section.title: ReadableIdProcessor
section.para: ReadableIdProcessor sets 'human readable' ids for each widget. Unlike UIViewRoot.createUniqueId, it tries to make the id readable both for debugging purposes and for when running unit tests (using, say, WebTest). Because the ids are based off the value binding (or method binding) of the UIComponent, this WidgetProcessor must come after StandardBindingProcessor (or equivalent).

Clients can plug in a different WidgetProcessor to use UIViewRoot.createUniqueId if preferred. They can even plug in assigning a changing, random id to a component each time it is generated. This is a great way to fox hackers who are trying to POST back pre-generated payloads of HTTP fields (i.e. CSRF attacks).

section.title: RequiredAttributeProcessor
section.para: RequiredAttributeProcessor sets UIInput.setRequired for any widgets with a required attribute.

section.title: RichFacesProcessor
section.para: RichFacesProcessor adds a RichFaces AJAX Support widget to any widgets with a faces-ajax-action attribute (for JSF 2.0, see also AjaxProcessor).

section.title: StandardBindingProcessor
section.para: StandardBindingProcessor attaches standard JSF value and action bindings to each widget.

section.title: StandardConverterProcessor
section.para: StandardConverterProcessor attaches standard JSF converters to each widget as needed. This includes DateTimeConverter and NumberConverter, and support for the faces-converter attribute.

section.title: StandardValidatorProcessor
section.para: StandardValidatorProcessor attaches standard JSF validators to each widget as needed. This includes DoubleRangeValidator, LongRangeValidator and LengthValidator.

section.title: HiddenFieldProcessor
section.para: Many Web applications store their data at the HttpServletRequest level, not at the HttpSession level. Using session-level state (or, ideally, a UI framework that supports some kind of 'conversation'-level state) is safer than passing variables to and from the client in hidden HTML fields. However, for those that need this approach HiddenFieldProcessor adds HTML hidden fields to read-only values, so that they POST back.
There are subclasses of HiddenFieldProcessor for JSP, Spring and Struts.

section.title: CaptionProcessor
section.para: CaptionProcessor calls setCaption on a Component, based on an uncamel-cased version of the business property name. This can then be used by Layouts such as org.metawidget.vaadin.ui.layout.FormLayout.

section.title: MinimumMaximumValidatorProcessor
section.para: MinimumMaximumValidatorProcessor adds a com.vaadin.data.Validator to a Component, based on either (or both) the Metawidget attributes minimum-value or maximum-value being set. These attributes can be set by, for example, using Hibernate Validator's @Range annotation.

section.title: RequiredProcessor
section.para: RequiredProcessor calls setRequired and setRequiredError on a Component, based on the Metawidget required attribute being set. This attribute can be set by, for example, using a @UiRequired annotation or Bean Validation's @NotNull annotation.

section.para: Like most other Metawidgets, VaadinMetawidget supports property binding.
